channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Media Merger With Nuclear Fusion Firm Raises Ethics Questions
item.description: Trump Media plans to merge with a company developing nuclear fusion technology, putting the president’s financial interests in competition with other energy companies over which his administration holds sway.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s social media company said on Thursday that it had agreed to an all-stock merger with TAE Technologies, a fusion power company.

item.title: A Somber Mood at Science Meeting as Trump Budget Cuts Continue
item.description: News of the breakup of a leading science institution rippled through an annual gathering of Earth, ocean and space scientists. Many say American science is suffering under the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Mark Makela/Reuters
item.media:description: The National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., is one of the world’s premier climate and weather science institutions.

item.title: She Tracked Fish That Coastal Communities Depend On. Then She Was Fired From NOAA.
item.description: Ana Vaz monitored crucial fish stocks in the Southeast and the Gulf of Mexico until she lost her job at NOAA.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times

item.title: Greenpeace’s Fight With Pipeline Giant Exposes a Legal Loophole
item.description: A court filing by a group with deep ties to the pipeline company Energy Transfer raises questions about the growing use of amicus briefs in litigation.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Nati Harnik/Associated Press
item.media:description: Energy Transfer pipes for the Dakota Access Pipeline in a staging area in Worthing, S.D., in 2015.

item.title: Hochul Repeals Rule Allowing New Customers Free Gas Hookups
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul struck down a decades-old provision that raised gas bills for millions of New Yorkers. The move could help curb the use of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s repeal of a rule that allowed for free gas hookups for some new customers was applauded by climate activists and other supporters.

item.title: Controversial Dakota Pipeline Gets a Big, Belated Government Boost
item.description: A delayed environmental review cleared the Dakota Access Pipeline to continue operating. Separately, a North Dakota judge expressed unusual exasperation over the tangled legal battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Thibaud Moritz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Activists in France earlier this year supporting Greenpeace, which is fighting a verdict against it that could bankrupt its U.S. operations.

item.title: Europe Begins to Tiptoe Away From Key Climate Policies
item.description: Europe has some of the world’s most ambitious climate goals, but in recent months it has backtracked on rules governing automobile emissions and deforestation.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Christophe Simon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Queuing for gas in southern France. Earlier this week, E.U. officials introduced a proposal that would walk back an effective ban on the production of gas- and diesel-powered cars by 2035.

item.title: Massachusetts Battery Start-Up to List on Stock Exchange
item.description: Factorial, the start-up, said the listing would provide money that would help it bring new solid-state batteries to market as soon as 2027.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Siyu Huang is the chief executive of Factorial.

item.title: BP Names New Boss After Its C.E.O. Steps Down
item.description: Meg O’Neill of Australia’s Woodside Energy will lead the British energy giant, replacing Murray Auchincloss, who will exit after less than two years in the role.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Hollie Adams/Reuters
item.media:description: Meg O’Neill, who will be BP’s first female chief executive, will start in April.

item.title: National Center for Atmospheric Research to Be Dismantled, Trump Administration Says
item.description: Russell Vought, the White House budget director, called the laboratory a source of “climate alarmism.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Brad Plumer and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Caine Delacy for The New York Times
item.media:description: National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., is responsible for many of the biggest scientific advances in humanity’s understanding of weather and climate since its founding in 1960.

item.title: Heating Costs Expected to Rise 9.2% This Winter
item.description: Colder weather and rising electricity and fuel costs will lead to a big jump in costs for individuals, according to estimates from a group representing state energy officials.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Higher electricity and natural gas prices coupled with unusually cold temperatures are expected to fuel more bill increases as the winter months settle in across the country.

item.title: What Can Iowa City Teach New York About Free Buses?
item.description: The Midwestern city went fare-free two years ago, mainly to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: James Barron
item.media:credit: Annick Sjobakken for The New York Times

item.title: Penguins Become Prey for the Pumas of Patagonia
item.description: In Argentina, the return of pumas brought top predators back to the landscape — much to penguins’ dismay.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: Research Flights Over the Atlantic Could Help Improve Atmospheric River Forecasting
item.description: A global effort to better understand moisture-laden rivers in the sky, like those currently battering the West Coast, will take flight in January.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: A view out the window of a research mission by NOAA into atmospheric rivers over the Pacific in 2023.

item.title: Commercializing the Arctic
item.description: Trump has shifted the U.S. approach to the Arctic, promoting oil and gas even as scientists have issued more dire warnings about the region.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Esther Horvath for The New York Times
item.media:description: Icebergs in Scoresby Sound on Greenland’s eastern coast in September.

item.title: U.S. Is Seeking Exemption From a European Climate Law, Officials Say
item.description: Diplomats told E.U. officials that the bloc’s law on methane, a potent greenhouse gas, would hurt American oil and gas companies.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: A liquified natural gas tanker. This year the Trump administration signed a deal with the European Union in which Europe pledged to buy American gas in exchange for tariff relief.

item.title: Arctic Report Card Marks Record Temperatures and Rainfall in Arctic
item.description: A yearly checkup on the region documents a warmer, rainier Arctic and 200 Alaskan rivers “rusting” as melting tundra leaches minerals from the soil into waterways.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Josh Koch/U.S. Geological Survey
item.media:description: A tributary of the Kugaaruk River in northern Alaska turning orange from elevated heavy metal concentrations.

item.title: Europe May Roll Back Combustion Engine Ban
item.description: A proposal to revise an E.U. law requiring carmakers to stop producing combustion engines by 2035 would offer some relief to automakers, but it sets back the region’s climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electric vehicles at a BMW factory in Munich. Premier automakers like BMW will benefit if an emission ban in Europe is rolled back.

item.title: Senators Investigate Role of A.I. Data Centers in Rising Electricity Costs
item.description: Three Democrats are seeking information from tech firms about the growing energy use of data centers and the utility bills of individuals and other businesses.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The energy needs of data centers used for artificial intelligence are forcing utility companies to spend billions of dollars to upgrade the power grid, the lawmakers said.

item.title: Ford Will Take $19.5 Billion Hit as It Rolls Back E.V. Plans
item.description: Ford Motor said the costs came from its decision to make fewer electric vehicles than it had planned and more hybrids that use both gasoline engines and batteries.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ford F-150 Lightning electric truck at the company’s plant in Dearborn, Mich., in 2022. The Lightning will no longer be a pure electric vehicle.

item.title: Hotels on Grand Canyon’s South Rim to Reopen After Water Line Repairs
item.description: The National Park Service said hotels on the South Rim could again welcome guests starting on Wednesday after repairs to a broken water pipeline.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Mauro Toccaceli/Shutterstock
item.media:description: Six hotels on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon, including the Bright Angel Lodge, are set to reopen on Wednesday after being closed since Dec. 6 for repairs to a water pipeline.

item.title: How the Pandemic Lockdowns Changed a Songbird’s Beak
item.description: For ecologists, the Covid-19 pandemic has presented a remarkable natural experiment in what can happen to wild animals when humans stay home.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Alex Fu
item.media:description: Dark-eyed juncos, normally forest-dwelling, have occupied Los Angeles for about 20 years.

item.title: Why New York Has Backed Off on Addressing Climate Change
item.description: With affordability and energy costs looming large as political issues, Gov. Kathy Hochul is less focused on going green.
item.dc:creator: James Barron
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times

item.title: MAHA Moms Are Angry at the E.P.A. Lee Zeldin Is Trying to Win Them Back.
item.description: A split is emerging within Trump’s base as health activists accuse Mr. Zeldin of leading the agency to prioritize chemical industry interests over public health.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Niki Chan Wylie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, appeared with Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in Salt Lake City earlier this year. Recently, Mr. Zeldin has gone on a charm offensive.

item.title: Reporting on Arctic Sovereignty in the Polar Bear Capital of the World
item.description: Global competition in the Arctic is raising hopes of a revival in the town of Churchill. We went to meet the people, and the bears, there.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Known in recent years mostly for its polar bears, there are now efforts to revive infrastructure in Churchill, Manitoba.

item.title: Clean, Limitless Energy Exists. China Is Going Big in the Race to Harness It.
item.description: Beijing is pouring vast resources into fusion research, while the U.S. wants private industry to lead the way. The winner could reshape civilization.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Harry Stevens

item.title: Harold Hamm, Oklahoma Oil Tycoon, Allies With Trump to Reshape U.S. Energy
item.description: Harold Hamm, an Oklahoma oil tycoon, has played a central role in reshaping energy policy by allying himself with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: Lawsuit Seeks to Stop Oil Exploration in Remote Areas of the Arctic
item.description: A federal lawsuit argues that proposed work by ConocoPhillips could threaten delicate ecosystems in the largest tract of public land in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: A ConocoPhillips oil drilling site on the North Slope of Alaska near the Willow site, another ConocoPhillips oil exploration project.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks FEMA From Canceling Climate Resiliency Grants
item.description: A Thursday ruling said the Trump administration cannot eliminate the Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities program without Congress.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A flood defense project on the East Side of Manhattan in 2021.

item.title: Trump Panel Abruptly Postpones Release of FEMA Overhaul Recommendations
item.description: The group’s report had been expected to provide a road map for change after months of upheaval at the agency.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry/Reuters
item.media:description: Talk of a FEMA overhaul comes as disasters are becoming more frequent and costly as a result of climate change.

item.title: Will the Self-Driving Cars of the Future Lower Emissions?
item.description: Waymo is rapidly expanding in the U.S. But experts say there are big questions about how self-driving cars could affect traffic and greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Balazs Gardi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Zoox self-driving robotaxi in San Francisco last month.

item.title: U.S. Helped to Weaken Report at U.N. Environment Talks, Participants Say
item.description: American officials joined Russia, Saudi Arabia and Iran in objecting to language on fossils fuels, biodiversity and plastics in a report that was three years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Monicah Mwangi/Reuters
item.media:description: The opening session of the 7th United Nations Environment Assembly in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday.

item.title: 100,000 in Washington State Ordered to Evacuate as Rivers Rise
item.description: Days of heavy rain pushed waterways to record flood levels in a mountainous region north of Seattle. “Do not wait,” local officials warned residents, urging them to seek higher ground.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin, Amy Graff and Drew Atkins
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Floodwaters poured over Springhetti Road in Snohomish, Wash.

item.title: Killer Whales Find an ‘Unlikely Friend’ in Dolphins
item.description: Off the coast of British Columbia, dolphins lead killer whales to salmon and earn their share of lunch, a new study reveals.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: She Studied Mosquitoes to Prevent Malaria. Then She Lost Her Job at U.S.A.I.D.
item.description: Jenny Carlson Donnelly traveled to malaria-affected countries to test mosquitoes and save lives. Then she lost her job at U.S.A.I.D.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times

item.title: Ford’s Car of the Future, Hatched in a Skunk Works Near Los Angeles
item.description: Desperate to catch up with Chinese automakers, Ford is redesigning its fleet with a Silicon Valley-style team. Is it too late?
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Field, Ford Motor Company’s chief of electric vehicles, digital and design.

item.title: New York’s Environmental Agenda Stalls Under Kathy Hochul
item.description: Faced with an affordability crisis and rising energy demands, Gov. Kathy Hochul has slowed progress on New York’s efforts to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York has embraced a pragmatic approach to high energy demand that some critics say has come at the cost of the state’s place at the forefront of the fight against climate change.

item.title: Lawsuit Challenges Park Service Passes Featuring Trump
item.description: An environmental group is suing, saying federal law requires an image of public lands, not the president.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow

item.title: Gregg Phillips, a Proponent of Election Conspiracy Theories, to Join FEMA
item.description: Gregg Phillips, who spread unsubstantiated claims of mass voter fraud in the 2016 election, will join the agency’s leadership, the Trump administration confirmed.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett/Reuters
item.media:description: Gregg Phillips, right, onstage in 2022 with Catherine Engelbrecht, with whom he has led True the Vote, a conservative nonprofit group.

item.title: Our Children’s Trust Suit Asks Montana Court to Block Some New Laws
item.description: The young plaintiffs, who won a major case over climate change policy in 2023, argue that legislators are illegally ignoring the effects of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rikki Held, the named plaintiff in Held v. Montana, in June 2023. The same plaintiffs are asking the state’s top court to prevent legislators from undermining their victory.

item.title: Starting With Formaldehyde, Trump Administration Reassesses Chemical Risks
item.description: A draft memo from the E.P.A. assumes a safe threshold exists for formaldehyde, upending earlier findings that there is no safe level of exposure to the carcinogen.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Between one to five billion pounds of formaldehyde is produced in the United States each year for a wide range of industries and products, including composite wood and other building materials, plastics, pesticides and even some hair straightening treatments.

item.title: Archaeologists Find Oldest Evidence of Fire-Making
item.description: Neanderthals 400,000 years ago were striking flints to make fires, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: How Can I Stop My Wife From Badgering Our Friends About Climate Change?
item.description: A reader’s wife is angry about what she sees as insufficient commitment to the cause of environmentalism, alienating the couple’s friends.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes
item.media:credit: Miguel Porlan

item.title: 50 States, 50 Fixes
item.description: We look at climate solutions across the country.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sifton
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: This Arkansas City Shows How to Slash Emissions and Save Money, Too
item.description: In the Ozarks, the growing college town of Fayetteville, Ark., is using clean energy to power city facilities and embracing nature-based solutions to climate threats.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Melyssa St. Michael
item.media:credit: Melyssa St. Michael for The New York Times

item.title: Wyoming Cowboys Are Breaking Down Barriers, Literally
item.description: GPS collars on cattle are letting ranchers remove fences in the West. That’s good for wildlife and for the land.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak and Will Warasila
item.media:credit: Will Warasila for The New York Times

item.title: Utah Tries Relocating Beavers to Save Them, and Remake the Landscape
item.description: Their dams cause floods, and that gets them in trouble with humans. But in the right place, more water can be a big help.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Kim Raff
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: Ranchers in South Dakota Turn to Prescribed Burns to Treat Their Land
item.description: A “green glacier” of trees is steadily taking over native grasslands. Landowners are banding together to treat the problem with fire.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: Not All Drilling in Texas Is About Oil
item.description: The state has become a hub of innovation for creating electricity using geothermal power. Just don’t call it renewable.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman and Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Kaylee Greenlee for The New York Times

item.title: For Real, a Natural History of Misinformation
item.description: It’s not just humans who suffer from leading one another astray. So do fish, flies and even bacteria.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Rob Stewart/Image Bank Film, via Getty Images

item.title: Some Mentions of Human Causes of Climate Change Removed From E.P.A. Site
item.description: An E.P.A. site listing the causes of climate change no longer includes the main one: human activity.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Ting Shen/Reuters
item.media:description: President Trump, who calls climate change a “hoax” is eliminating restrictions on coal, oil and gas while imposing new ones on renewable energy like wind and solar.
